abstract: <jats:p>Genome‐wide association (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWA</jats:styled-content>) studies have identified several pancreatic cancer (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>an<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>a) susceptibility loci. Methods for assessment of polygenic susceptibility can be employed to detect the collective effect of additional association signals for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>an<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>a. Using data on 492,651 autosomal single nucleotide polymorphisms (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s) from the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>an<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">S</jats:styled-content>can <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWA</jats:styled-content> study (2,857 cases, 2,967 controls), we employed polygenic risk score (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PRS</jats:styled-content>) cross‐validation (<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CV</jats:styled-content>) methods to (a) confirm the existence of unidentified association signals, (b) assess the predictive value of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PRS</jats:styled-content>s, and (c) assess evidence for polygenic effects in specific genomic locations (genic vs. intergenic). After excluding <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s in known <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>an<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>a susceptibility regions, we constructed <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PRS</jats:styled-content> models using a training <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWA</jats:styled-content> dataset and then tested the model in an independent testing dataset using fourfold <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CV</jats:styled-content>. We also employed a “power‐replication” approach, where power to detect <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content> associations was calculated using a training dataset, and power was tested for association with “replication status” in a testing dataset. <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PRS</jats:styled-content> scores constructed using ≥10% of genome‐wide <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s showed significant association with <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>an<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>a (<jats:italic><jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content></jats:italic>< 0.05) across the majority of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">CV</jats:styled-content> analyses. Associations were stronger for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PRS</jats:styled-content>s restricted to genic <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s compared to intergenic <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PRS</jats:styled-content>s. The power‐replications approach produced weaker associations that were not significant when restricting to <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">SNP</jats:styled-content>s with low pairwise linkage disequilibrium, whereas <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PRS</jats:styled-content> results were robust to such restrictions. Although the <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">PRS</jats:styled-content> approach will not dramatically improve <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>an<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>a prediction, it provides strong evidence for unidentified association signals for <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>an<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>a. Our results suggest that focusing association studies on genic regions and conducting larger <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">GWA</jats:styled-content> studies can reveal additional <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">P</jats:styled-content>an<jats:styled-content style="fixed-case">C</jats:styled-content>a susceptibility loci. Genet. Epidemiol. 36:517‐524, 2012. © 2012 Wiley Periodicals, Inc.</jats:p>

reference.article-title: Increased risk of incident pancreatic cancer among first‐degree relatives of patients with familial pancreatic cancer
reference.author: Tersmette AC

title: Unidentified Genetic Variants Influence Pancreatic Cancer Risk: An Analysis of Polygenic Susceptibility in the <scp>P</scp>an<scp>S</scp>can Study
